A lot of people are saying you can turn a ship fast enough to avoid a missile, but you really can. A lot of big missiles are ballistic in trajectory, so unlike cruise missiles they don’t change course, only make minor corrections to stay on their trajectory, so very easy to predict. Also, unlike hellfires and TOW missiles they’re not actively guided, as in, receiving targeting updates. You give them a location, say have a blast, and send them on their way.

The math to avoid is fairly simple.

Take an average ballistic missile, say an Iskander, max speed 2600 m/s. Remembering that max speed is going to be in the terminal, and that from launch to apogee (max ord) it’ll be starting from 0 and gaining speed. Let’s give the missile an average of 1500 m/s.

Assuming the carrier strike group is 30 miles out to see, so, ~45km.

45000 meters assuming a generous average of 1500 meters a second gives us 30 seconds to move the ship from where it was going to be to anywhere else. Even turning hard to simply bleed speed would work to move the 1092 ft long flight deck out of the predicted point of impact. Especially if you turn the ship perpendicular to the flight path now the target zone is only 252 feet wide and increases the likelihood the missile will over or under shoot the target. Artillery and missiles don’t average their impacts in circles, but in ovals with the greatest deviation based on the gun to target line (gtl).

Allllll that said, this is still probably a “someone fucked up and we’re gonna try to play it off” thing. I can’t say I haven’t seen and done the same thing before, just, not to this scale.
